HE interest manifested by the people of Mary-
land with regard to education dates back to Co-
lonial times. The first general free-school law was a
- petitionary Act, passed in 1696, of which the first
section reads as follows: “ And may it be enacted
by the King’s most excellent majesty, by and with
the advice, prayer, and consent of this present Gen-
eral Assembly, and the authority of the same, that
for the propagation of the gospel and the education
of the youth of this province in good letters and
manners, that a certain place or places for a free
- school or schools, or place of study of Latin, Greek,
Writing, and the like, consisting of one master, one
usher, and one writing-master or scribe to a school

and one hundred scholars, more or less, according to

the ability of the said free school, may be made,
erected, founded, propagated, and established, under
your royal patronage. And that the most reverend
father in God, Thomas, by Divine Providence Arch-
bishop of Canterbury, primate and Metropolitan of
all England, may be chancellor of the said schools;
and that, to perpetuate the memory of your Majesty,
it may be called King William’s School, etc., ete.”
(This school is still in existence under the name of
St. John’s College.) The Act goes on to provide
~ that as soon as the income of King William’s School
“amounts to one hundred and twenty pounds sterling
per annum, the trustees shall proceed to erect a
gecond free school “at the town of Oxford, on the
eastern shore of this province.” ¢“And also, after
~ the second free school is built, erected, founded, and
furnished, the said rectors, governors, and visitors
shall, as fast as they shall be enabled as aforesaid,
proceed to the erecting of other and more free
schools in this province; that is to say, in every

prayed that it may be enacted, etc., etc.” The law
goes on to enact that a free school shall be estab-
lished in each county, under the superintendence
and control of what we may call a “State Board of
Education,” the members of which are specified by
name in the Act. This Board is required to meet
four times a year, at least; and, among other things,
they are directed to ¢ take all proper methods for the
encouraging good schoolmasters that shall be mem-
bers of the Church of England, and of pious and
exemplary lives and conversations, and capable of
teaching well the grammar, good writing, and the
mathematics, if such can conveniently be got, and
that they allow every such master for his encourage-
ment for the present (besides the benefit and use of
his plantation) [fifty acres], the sum of twenty pounds
per annum.” Under this Act several schools were
established, some of which survive to the present
day; but the funds allowed by law were too small
and too uncertain to produce anything like a general
free-school system. Among other sources of income
we find that clerks not writing a legible hand are to
pay 2,000 1bs. of tobacco, one-half to go to the free-
school fund; the owner of hogs running at large is
to pay 100 lbs. of tobacco to the pubhc schools;
the owner of geese running at large is to pay ten
shillings to the school fund; the fine for sell-
ing liquor within three miles of Friends’ Yearly
Meeting is five pounds, of which one-half is to go
to the public schools; the fine for harboring slaves
is 100 1bs. of tobacco per hour, one-half to be given
to the public schools, and the other half to the

\



tinued (at least on the statute book) till near the
Revolution.

The Revolutionary War proved a serious obstacle
to the progress of education. At its close, many of
the county academies began to show symptoms of
decay; and before the end of the eighteenth cen-
tury, the free-school fund in several counties was
transferred to the commissioners of the poor. Up
to the year 1865, no general system of free schools
was in operation, though every county had a system
(more or less efficient) of its own, supported to a
very limited extent by a State Fund, but mainly by
local taxation. In 1865, the present system, of which
Maryland is justly proud, was inaugurated upon the
basis of the grand principle that the property of the
State shall be held responsible for the education of
the children of the State.

Among many noble men to whose exertions the -
people of Maryland owe this great triumph, two
may be named as most conspicuous— Joseph M.
Cushing, Chairman of the Committee of Education
in the Constitutional Convention of 1864, and Li-
bertus Van Bokkelen, first State Superintendent of
Public Instruction. Three successive legislatures
have made many changes in the original school law,
but the main features are still preserved, — < Educa-
tion absolutely free, and an open highway in which

- who will may walk from the Primary School to the

University.” The last change of importance was
made in 1872, and placed the schools for colored
children on the same footing and under the same
regulations as schools for white children.
